@niketanpansare - there's one additional problem here. In JMLC we can have inputs which are not cleaned up by `rmvar` but for which `isCleanupEnabled = true`. So these pointers end up being freed by `guardedCudaFree` in `clearTemporaryMemory`, but the associated GPUObject remains in `GPUMatrixMemoryManager.gpuObjects`. We then try to free this pointer again the next time the script is invoked and we get an exception. An example would be the feature vector for prediction. These change each time a prepared script is invoked (so `isCleanupEnabled = true`), but are not cleaned up by an `rmvar` instruction. 

This causes a single `Pointer` to be associated with several different `GPUObjects` which can cause us to try and free a pointer twice leading to an exception. We could fix this issue by adding a method which removes non-dirty, unlocked, GPUObjects for which cleanup is enabled from the memory manager as part of the logic for `GPUContext.cleanupTemporaryMemory()`. However, this will add a performance cost as we need to do an extra scan of the list of GPUObjects. Note that it's not clear to me why these variables are not cleaned up by `rmvar` in JMLC.

well, although I don't know the details here, if the prediction vectors are passed from outside into JMLC then we can't compile a rmvar because a user might still want to use the variable afterwards (or even pass it into another prepared script invocation). 

If the GPU cleanup is an issue, you might want to think about something like Spark's ContextCleaner, which simply registers a weak reference on the object and listens on its queue - if the weak reference is cleared, you know the application program can't reach the object anymore and hence it can be lazily cleaned up from the GPU memory manager. Spark uses the same for RDDs, broadcasts, accumulators, etc.

Thanks @niketanpansare looks good to me - :+1: A quick comparison indicates that JMLC is now in the ballpark of TF/Keras at small batch sizes. However, at larger batch sizes we're still a bit slower - I have not yet had a chance to dig into what exactly is going on in detail. However, `nvprof` indicates that the most costly operations are convolution followed by device to host transfer, so there may still be some unnecessary copying going on. We can address this in follow up though. See below for numbers (all computation in single precision):

| Batch Size | SystemML (Sec.) | TensorFlow (Sec.) |
|------------|-----------------|-------------------|
| 1          | 0.031           | 0.024             |
| 2          | 0.043           | 0.021             |
| 4          | 0.076           | 0.037             |
| 8          | 0.137           | 0.076             |
| 16         | 0.257           | 0.146             |
| 32         | 0.468           | 0.273             |
| 64         | 0.818           | 0.426             |
| 128        | 2.97            | 0.849             |

@niketanpansare - this looks good to me and I confirm resolves the performance issues we noted earlier. I had originally thought we should extend this to objects allocated on the CPU as well. However, `rmvar` already removes references to these objects from the symbol table, so I think they can be garbage collected by the JVM under memory pressure. Do you agree?

Hi @opengjenkins - thanks for adding this example notebook.

Your notebook is fine, have two nice examples. Also, your [dml script](https://github.com/apache/systemml/blob/b9f9cb85fd3807915939113d76b358a58319effa/scripts/staging/Kmeans-functional.dml) in well into `11` nice funcs of which `4` main funcs.

Although, this is good enough. Since the top level [K-means script](https://github.com/apache/systemml/blob/master/scripts/algorithms/Kmeans.dml) is well tested, reusing most of it can scale your algorithm even better.

PS: A functionalized K-means could help us lead the deep learning support path for systemml
 - one DL + kmean example is [Deep-K-Means](https://github.com/Sandbox3aster/Deep-K-Means-pytorch)
i.e., applying k-means clustering on the weights, compression is achieved through weight sharing and storing only the center of the clusters. Also, the compression ratio could be as much as `40%`!

Well, if the goal is simply to add an fm layer, then I guess its fine (I wasn't suggesting adding a standalone dml implementation).

I looked for documentation on nn layers and seems like we have very sparse docs. For instance, I couldn't find any documentation explaining at an intuitive, abstract level what conv2d does. That's what I was suggesting. For the standalone dml algos we have a pdf file with such info.

So feel free to ignore my previous comment. Seems like the comments in the fm layer's implementation are supposed to serve as sufficient description.

Setup:
```
N = 64
tmp = 0
for(i in 1:100) {
        [output, c, cache] = lstm::forward(x, w, b, return_seq, out0, c0)
        [dX, dW, db, dout0, dc0] = lstm::backward(output, c, x, w, b, return_seq, out0, c0, cache)
        c0 = c
        tmp = tmp - sum(dX) + sum(dW) - sum(dout0) + sum(db) - sum(dc0)
}
print(tmp)
```

mvn package -P distribution

@romeokienzler You are getting the error because the setup contains two SystemML (possibly conflicting dependencies) jars. There are two possible solutions to your problem:
1. *Recommended:* Remove the older incubating jar and do not include the corresponding 1.2.0 or 1.3.0-snapshot jars (i.e. no need for `ln -s` trick).
2. Use the python package compiled by this PR.

Interestingly, running a similar code with `1.2.0` jars in `spark-2.3.0../spark-shell` succeeds, i.e. behaves similar to setup 5 rather than setup 6. Here is the Scala code used for testing:

```
val ml = new org.apache.sysml.api.mlcontext.MLContext(spark)
System.out.println(ml.version())
val df = spark.read.parquet("shake.parquet")
df.show()
df.createOrReplaceTempView("df")
```

Based on the above experiments, here are my thoughts:
1. We can continue to support older Spark 2.1 version and can get away with warning on Spark 2.3 in the following setups:
- Invoked without any Spark SQL code
- Part of Scala/Java pipeline (for example: if invoked via spark-shell)
- With PySpark if and only if we recommend our users to not provide any jars in the `driver-class-path or jars` (see setup 5 and 6)
2. If we are uncomfortable with the above restriction, we should consider merging this PR.
- Though I have validated that above Python code works with Spark 2.2.3 with a warning, I did not run exhaustive testing to guarantee backward compatibility support for older Spark 2.1 and 2.2 (with the exception of warning).

Note, some tests are failing in python federated.
This is intentionally left in, so that we at some point can go back and fix the underlying functionality.

1. bug is if you create a federated matrix that is not 100% filled in by federated workers, then operations does not take into account the remaining cells.
2. bug is if you create a federated matrix that is larger than the input size, it crashes, while expected behavior is to pad the matrix with 0's for consistent behavior, with other functionality.
3. feature/bug, currently if a single federated matrix is having overlapping sub matrices, see tests ["federated basic test"](/src/main/python/tests/federated/test_federated_basic) for examples, the system does not complain, and in some cases even works by overwriting the matrix values of the first selected federated matrix with the later matrices.
